item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Bowser jr:

Did I get it wrong that Geert opposed the Cabinet he first supported, in the issue of the policies that Merkel want to push to the European countries?

He dropped his support because he didn’t want to support the austerity package the government was planning. He agreed with most parts of it, but in the end he got scared of the reactions from the Dutch citizens. He’ll never tell the truth about it though, and no politician nor most of the voters take him serious.

You either put pressure on Greece and force them to comply with the promises they made, or you let them take their time and they’ll comply with their promises much later. The former is the best for the European countries, except Greece. The latter is best for Greece, but it could cause a domino effect and we’ll be rescuing Spain and Italy next. I don’t know if that will happen, but I wouldn’t want to risk it. On the other hand, I wonder if Greece will be able to comply, even if all Greek citizens supported the measures. Of course it isn’t ‘left wing’ to force Greece to cut their deficit, but I’d put part of the blame of the deficit on the left wing. Greece has been a leftist country for quite some time now. Germany on the other hand is centre-right, and is doing great.

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Frell: While I’m against people getting rich by working hard and smart a short period and later exploiting people, I’m not attacking them here. I’m only speaking of wages now, not money gained by your company growing. I hope you understands that difference. I’m speaking of a way of wage control that makes the wealth of a company flow in a bit more fair way. I know that no American would support my other idea of fixing it (socialism). And you can’t cry about high wages with my system, as if your business have problem, you just have to adjust everyone’s wages.

What I’m speaking of is people like the CEO of Statkraft, who get too much paid, but is employed by an even richer owner. He didn’t build the company, so no he isn’t the one who look for nice places to build hydro-power plants.
The CEO of the most successful Norwegian company Statoil, doesn’t look for oil himself, he have people employed to do it, and if things go bad he get lots of money anyway.

Small business owners doesn’t get hurt by this, they gain if the company gains money. As said earlier, the difference between the best and worst paid isn’t written in stone.

item.title: Worlds richest woman claims poor people should work harder
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:62, topic:457440”]Another alternative if you don’t want to raise the minimum wage.
Nobody can earn more than twice (Or 3x, depending on how generous you are) the salary of the person earning the least amount of money. This of course is adjusted to actual work hours and taken the real wage into account, to prevent any trickery.[/quote]

That’s a stupid idea, and I agree with Frell. Take Statkraft, a Norwegian electricity company. Most of it’s power supply comes from hydroelectric plants, so as far as renewability goes it’s one of the better companies. The CEO earns around $700.000. If the cleaning lady should earn 3 times less money, she’d still earn $233.000. That’s absurd, and would cause hyperinflation.

Besides, a cleaning lady working for a small business would only earn around $20.000, so your so-called wealth distribution will only result in more class struggle, only now cleaning lady’s driving cars will run over their less-earning counterparts who walk to their work because they can’t even afford a bicycle thanks to inflation.

IMO, the distribution of wealth in most European countries is good as it is right now. The extremely poor receive welfare and other forms of financial help, and the rich pay a decent amount of taxes that both funnels money back to the poor and still encourages people to aim for the top. CEO’s usually are assholes, but the layer directly below them, highly trained engineers and the like, should earn more money than the average bum because they are superior to the average bum (when it comes to doing the job they are doing). CEO’s earn a lot, but it’s usually in proportion to the revenue of the company.

Banks are cannon fodder these days, and they deserve it. But don’t use the same arguments you use against banks to attack other company’s.
